Comment: >So I'm wondering what has changed with immigration policy since he came into office.  Biden, immediately after inauguration, halted construction of the border wall by ending the "national immigration emergency" Trump was using to get funds for the wall after being rebuked by Congress. He also ended the "Muslim ban" on 14 countries of largely Islamic population. He also immediately reinforced support for the "Dreamers", a policy Trump had tried to unilaterally end as well. He also pushed for a Congressional bill that would create a "pathway to citizenship" for illegal immigrants in the US.  Biden had appointed Harris to handle international relations for immigration (this is why the right called her the "border czar"). She wasn't actually tasked with the border, but instead attempted to work internationally to discover the root cause of why the immigrants were coming here and try to develop diplomatic solutions to reduce the need for them to immigrate in the first place.  Biden raised the refugee cap (which was lowered to 15k per year under Trump) to 125k by 2024.  Biden ended Trump's "Remain in Mexico" policy, which required people seeking asylum from Mexico to remain in Mexico and return to the US when their court date was set.   Recently, after the failure of the border bill in Congress in spring 2024, Biden has implemented a cap of 2500 illegal migrant encounters daily, with any excess encounters being immediately deported back to Mexico.      There's a lot more individual acts, but generally Biden has supported legal and illegal immigration more, attempted to act more "humanely" to these illegal immigrants, and reverted back to more of Obama's stance on immigration, though he's recently taken a more hard line as illegal immigration surges.  >Are we close to approaching open border policy? Is it all just overblown?   It is an issue, as illegal immigration is certainly up. But in no way is it an "open border" policy, and Border Patrol continues to do their job and deportations and encounters continue to rise.   We are not approaching an open border policy, but we could certainly use more funds, BP agents, and immigration judges and attorneys to make the border operate better.
